pros: Useful skills, you learn a bit of a trade in coffee making and everyone always wants to talk to you about your job. You work so closely with people that it's almost impossible not to make strong relationships. You learn to be fast, good with people, organized, and self-reliant. The benefits are really worth it though. You get good healthcare with only 20 hours min a week, 401K, and vacation/sick time. Also free college, therapy, Spotify, coffee every day, and stock.
cons: You are constantly short staffed. They keep you purposely short staffed. But that means you can always pick up hours and no one really cares when you go into overtime. Also, the pay is almost embarrassingly low at this point. Adding in tips, you get a little more than minimum wage. And still less than any other competitor. We make two dollars less than McDonalds and Panera. Places like Chipoltle and Target make $3-$4 more an hour in my state. They don't really give raises. They just bump up starting pay when minimum wage raises. I've been at the company four years, and before I got promoted I made the same as all the new people coming in. And even though I've been a shift for two years, I make the same as the shifts getting started now. So, it's just a constant line of pay, and no matter how good you are you'll always make the same as the worst person on staff. And the work is really hard. Harder than almost any retail job I've ever had and I've had some rough ones. Starbucks workers do all of the making/cleaning/stocking while being understaffed and with not even close to enough hours in the day. Starbucks has the highest cleaning standards of any food service job you've ever seen, and they are unrealistic about what goes into keeping that standard up. You will sweat and run and get yelled at and still make the same wage as the guy who calls off every other Saturday.

job_title: Front End Developer in Glendale, CA
pros:
1. Starbucks' hiring process is contingent on both parties' mutual availability.
(If your employer needs a specific shift (open, mid, close) covered and your schedule permits, your probability of landing the job is significantly higher.

2. Starbucks stands true to its core values: inclusion, diversity, and equity.
(Starbucks hires individuals from all walks of life. If you're a decent moral agent that can communicate and follow through well, then you're game.)

3. Unlimited drinks and one food item before, during, or after a shift is offered to all partners.
(Discounts and markouts on anything in the store)
cons:
1. Lack of effective downward communication facilitates an inadequate work environment for its partners and managers. (A transparent dialogue and place to facilitate that conversation amongst its staff would be a start)

2. Developing tough skin and acceptance to constructive criticism towards belligerent consumers and neutral staff is necessary.

3. It is unfortunate to have little to no training and be thrown into a peak (hell) when starting as a partner. It's unacceptable to have shift manager/team members berate (in front of consumers/everyone in the store) you for your lack of experience and knowledge to adapt. (This experience only happens to some if a specific Starbucks lacks the proper scheduling and funding to train. Countless partners and I have faced this type of experience and no apology/statement has been implemented .)

review_title: A solid and reputable company, but has inconsistencies in management.
pros: Amazing benefits (health, dental, 401(k), etc.), especially since it includes part-time employees. You do not find that often in an employer.
cons:
Note: I was employed at Starbucks for 4 years (2005-2009). Glassdoor did not have the option to select that date range, so I wanted to make that disclaimer.

---------

There were two main cons during my experience:

1. Starbucks does provide guidelines and training materials that are consistent in all its retail stores. However, in each of the four locations I was assigned to during my tenure had interpreted the guidelines differently, and the inconsistency of management practices made it especially difficult for me to work there. There were also significant inconsistencies in how Shift Supervisors perceive the rules and protocols. This can make it difficult for Baristas because it forces them to learn how to perform the tasks according to how each Shift Supervisor wanted the tasks to be performed (examples include making drinks, cleaning expresso machines, cash till handling, marking out pastries, mopping floor mats, and cleaning bathrooms). 

2. I worked in 4 stores during my tenure, and it saddens me to acknowledge that in every one of those 4 locations, I experienced disability discrimination from several supervisors, assistant managers, and managers, and a few ADA violations had also occurred. In addition, I discovered after some investigation that in 3 of the 4 store locations I made to become promoted to Shift Supervisor, the management had set up requirements for me that were more complex and difficult than most of the Shift Supervisors I had spoken to. As a result, I was never able to reach that goal during my four years of tenure.

There was one attempt I made to contact Starbucks' Human Resources department to file a complaint against one of my managers. Unfortunately, that was going to involve myself being identified by the manager and I was (at the time) afraid that I would be laid off from my job if I fully came out as having a disability. As a result, I withdrew my complaint so that I could protect myself and my employment. After 4 years of exercising patience and hoping the experience as an employee at Starbucks would improve, I finally had to resign to take care of mental health issues that occurred as a result of working there. 

-----------------

Having said all this, I am incredibly aware that my personal experience does not represent the experiences of other past and current employees, and it is not a reflection of the company as a whole. It's important to point out there are employees with disabilities who have had an amazing and supportive experience working for Starbucks.

This is a very difficult topic for me to open up about because personal experiences are so diversified. However, I feel it is important to share so that if by chance you are reading this, you at least have the awareness that discrimination among coworkers and management (including disability discrimination) does occur and it is not just limited to one Starbucks store location.

I know that for many people who work or have worked for Starbucks, it has been a positive experience. Positive experiences should be treated just as valid as negative experiences. For certain people, Starbucks is an excellent place to work. In no way do I want to discourage anyone who wants to work there. However, it is not for everyone.

cons: Starbucks should pay everyone more: corporate partners and barista partners. review_title: Your Experience Will Be Entirely Based On The Store You Work At
pros: The benefits are good considering it's a part-time service job, but the pay is minimal. If you're not against working early mornings, it's a great job to have while balancing others responsibilities because you can go in early and leave early. The best thing I got out of the job were the friendships, as corny as it sounds, but this is highly influence by the culture of the specific store you end up at.
cons: There's a lot of incompetent managers out there who overwork their baristas and supervisors. The job can be mentally and physically debilitating. To improve numbers, managers will cut back on necessary inventory and cut labor hours, and will then get upset with their baristas when customer surveys comeback complaining about items being sold out and baristas not being attentive enough.
